timeline.bodyText: should not it be added by Operators#addCap() ?

replies.bodyText: indeed better to use capped add 👍
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText: it will take a lot of time to go down to zero, but anyway why to decrement for a fast path?
timeline.author: robotmrv

replies.bodyText: not sure what you mean. maybe that this decrement operation should be skipped in case fastpath == true ?
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: we need to keep separate track of "how many buffers are wanted by downstream" (REQUESTED_BUFFERS) vs "how many elements have been requested upstream" (REQUESTED_FROM_SOURCE), so that when we're filling a buffer and we see that said buffer is not yet full, we only ask the source for one more element IFF there is no pending request to it already. Otherwise, we know that we should soon receive at least another element which might fulfill the buffer.
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText:
maybe that this decrement operation should be skipped in case fastpath == true ?

yes, I mean this
replies.author: robotmrv

replies.bodyText: updated, by extracting if (fastpath) return true; we take care of the fastpath case more clearly and avoid these atomic operations altogether
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.message:
fix #1937 Account for requests made to upstream in FluxBufferPredicate

This commit adds additional request accounting to FluxBufferPredicate,
allowing it to keep track of when there is remaining upstream request
and when there is not. In turn, this allows the "just add to buffer"
case to perform an additional `request(1)` ONLY if necessary (to further
fill the current buffer).

timeline.bodyText:
@simonbasle I have one question about that you said before
#2027 (comment)

a Subscriber is responsible for ensuring the upstream requests it makes are not done in parallel (rule 2.7) so that line MUST NOT be executed at the same time

as far as I understand s.request() could be invoked from BufferPredicateSubscriber#request() and from BufferPredicateSubscriber#onNext() and they could be invoked by different Threads.
How does rule 2.7 is satisfied here or it is not applicable here?
timeline.author: robotmrv

replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: the above doesn't seem to be necessary. I have added tests around racing request and onNext and validated the current code doesn't lead to backpressure errors.
replies.author: simonbasle
